posts.title: Why am I here?
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"# Short story
I wanted to try [Vultr](https://www.vultr.com/?ref=7230061), [ghost](https://ghost.org/) and deploy something in node.. 

# Long story
I want to share knowledge and become more active in the tech community. Also being capable to deploy my own shit.
I had a wordpress blog with some few posts, but I was already tired of it. Let me embrace new technologies and more interesting development stuff.

Just changed from [Digital Ocean](https://m.do.co/c/93638281c46a) to [Vultr](https://www.vultr.com/?ref=7230061). The 5$ option in Vultr has double the RAM, it's a no brainer for small stuff like this.

In this VPS, for now, I'm just hosting a website for a non-profit that has literally no visits [Green World Community](https://gworldcommunity.org) (go for it and give me one visit), my [homepage](https://odopeyone.xyz) that just has a Pascal Triangle built with dots in [p5js](https://p5js.org/) and some other insignificant experiences.

Also using [Caddy](https://caddyserver.com/), such an awesome webserver and easy to use! 
Wordpress PHP is configured with fpm and nodejs ghost app is just a reverse proxy that leads to pm2. Finally getting to understand this stuff :)

I'll leave here my CaddyFile so that it may help someone lost in the internet.

```
https://odopeyone.xyz {
        root /var/www/odopeyone.xyz/public_html
        gzip
        log /etc/caddy/log/odopeyone.xyz.log
        errors /etc/caddy/log/odopeyone.xyz.errors
}

https://gworldcommunity.org {
       root /var/www/gworldcommunity.org/public_html
       gzip
       fastcgi / /var/run/php/php7.0-fpm.sock php # Foi preciso mudar as permissoes da socket para o worker
       log /etc/caddy/log/gworldcommunity.org.log
       errors /etc/caddy/log/gworldcommunity.org.errors
       rewrite {
               if {path} not_match ^\/wp-admin
               to {path} {path}/ /index.php?{query}
       }
}

https://blog.odopeyone.xyz {
       proxy / localhost:2368
}

```

BTW, looks good this ghost platform. Kinda liking it. (y)
"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:

I wanted to try Vultr, ghost and deploy something in node..

Long story

I want to share knowledge and become more active in the tech community. Also being capable to deploy my own shit.
I had a wordpress blog with some few posts, but I was already tired of it. Let me embrace new technologies and more interesting development stuff.

Just changed from Digital Ocean to Vultr. The 5$ option in Vultr has double the RAM, it's a no brainer for small stuff like this.

In this VPS, for now, I'm just hosting a website for a non-profit that has literally no visits Green World Community (go for it and give me one visit), my homepage that just has a Pascal Triangle built with dots in p5js and some other insignificant experiences.

Also using Caddy, such an awesome webserver and easy to use!
Wordpress PHP is configured with fpm and nodejs ghost app is just a reverse proxy that leads to pm2. Finally getting to understand this stuff :)

I'll leave here my CaddyFile so that it may help someone lost in the internet.

https://odopeyone.xyz {
        root /var/www/odopeyone.xyz/public_html
        gzip
        log /etc/caddy/log/odopeyone.xyz.log
        errors /etc/caddy/log/odopeyone.xyz.errors
}

https://gworldcommunity.org {
       root /var/www/gworldcommunity.org/public_html
       gzip
       fastcgi / /var/run/php/php7.0-fpm.sock php # Foi preciso mudar as permissoes da socket para o worker
       log /etc/caddy/log/gworldcommunity.org.log
       errors /etc/caddy/log/gworldcommunity.org.errors
       rewrite {
               if {path} not_match ^\/wp-admin
               to {path} {path}/ /index.php?{query}

https://blog.odopeyone.xyz {

}

BTW, looks good this ghost platform. Kinda liking it. (y)

Pascal Triangle built with dots in p5js [https://p5js.org/]  and some other
insignificant experiences.

Also using Caddy [https://caddyserver.com/], such an awesome webserver and easy
to use!
Wordpress PHP is configured with fpm and nodejs ghost app is just a reverse
proxy that leads to pm2. Finally getting to understand this stuff :)

I'll leave here my CaddyFile so that it may help someone lost in the internet.

https://odopeyone.xyz {

        errors /etc/caddy/log/odopeyone.xyz.errors
}

https://gworldcommunity.org {
       root /var/www/gworldcommunity.org/public_html

       log /etc/caddy/log/gworldcommunity.org.log

}

https://blog.odopeyone.xyz {
       proxy / localhost:2368
}



BTW, looks good this ghost platform. Kinda liking it. (y)
posts.custom_excerpt: I want to share knowledge and become more active in the tech community. Also being capable to deploy my own shit.

posts.title: Amazon Inventory Template File - SKU vs Product-id
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"# What's the difference between Amazon SKU and Product-id?
I am currently integrating our ecommerce platform with Amazon, trying to do it the easiest way.

For now I've discovered that if you use the *Inventory Template File* you just need to provide suficient info so that Amazon can match your product with an existing one in there.

> At first I was constantly getting **column header** errors

At first I was constantly getting **column header** errors (90061 or 90043) and the reason was the template file. Different markets can have different template files. You should always download them through the *seller central* as I was trying to use the *.com* to update products to the *.es* market.

Understanding it I needed to provide the main field so that Amazon could match the products.

SKU or Product-Id? **Product-Id**

SKU means *Stock Keeping Unit* and is for you, the seller, to organize your inventory. Normally you would use some mechanism to organize them, like some product reference + variation shortcode + date of entrance. It can be anything you understand.

Product-Id is the product's barcode. It is code per product variation, if appliable, and must be a [UPC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Product_Code), [EAN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Article_Number), [GTIN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Trade_Item_Number) or [ASIN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_Standard_Identification_Number).

This is the field that matches your product with an existing one in Amazon and frees you from having to supply all the product information.

Hope this helps someone and leave some comment with your opinion about the post.



"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
What's the difference between Amazon SKU and Product-id?

I am currently integrating our ecommerce platform with Amazon, trying to do it the easiest way.

For now I've discovered that if you use the Inventory Template File you just need to provide suficient info so that Amazon can match your product with an existing one in there.

At first I was constantly getting column header errors

At first I was constantly getting column header errors (90061 or 90043) and the reason was the template file. Different markets can have different template files. You should always download them through the seller central as I was trying to use the .com to update products to the .es market.

Understanding it I needed to provide the main field so that Amazon could match the products.

SKU or Product-Id? Product-Id

SKU means Stock Keeping Unit and is for you, the seller, to organize your inventory. Normally you would use some mechanism to organize them, like some product reference + variation shortcode + date of entrance. It can be anything you understand.

Product-Id is the product's barcode. It is code per product variation, if appliable, and must be a UPC, EAN, GTIN or ASIN.

This is the field that matches your product with an existing one in Amazon and frees you from having to supply all the product information.

Hope this helps someone and leave some comment with your opinion about the post.
posts.plaintext:
What's the difference between Amazon SKU and Product-id?
I am currently integrating our ecommerce platform with Amazon, trying to do it
the easiest way.

For now I've discovered that if you use the Inventory Template File  you just
need to provide suficient info so that Amazon can match your product with an
existing one in there.

At first I was constantly getting column header  errors

At first I was constantly getting column header  errors (90061 or 90043) and the
reason was the template file. Different markets can have different template
files. You should always download them through the seller central  as I was
trying to use the .com  to update products to the .es  market.

Understanding it I needed to provide the main field so that Amazon could match
the products.

SKU or Product-Id? Product-Id

SKU means Stock Keeping Unit  and is for you, the seller, to organize your
inventory. Normally you would use some mechanism to organize them, like some
product reference + variation shortcode + date of entrance. It can be anything
you understand.

posts.title: Wordpress asking for FTP credentials in VPS
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Normally if you install WordPress on a shared host, it is very straightforward. You don't even need to think about the FTP user in order to upload plugins or update the base code.

If you, instead, have it set up in a VPS, like digital ocean or Vultr, like me, that might not be as simple as that and will depend on how your server is configured.

## My Setup
* webserver: caddy + php-fpm
* caddy owned by user1
* fpm owned by www-data

With a setup like this, the important is to know who owns the fpm process.

You can check it with:
```ps aux | grep fpm``` -> mine is www-data, I will assume it.

This will tell you that the user *www-data* who needs **write** file access is the user who owns that process.

So, your WordPress folder should be owned by *www-data*. This is the first point.
The second one is that the caddy user owner must be in the *www-data* group so that it also has permissions to handle the files if needed.

After you have the users organized, you must include a line of code in *wp-config.php* file.
```define('FS_METHOD', 'direct');```


These were the steps I needed to solve my upload problems. 
Hope it can help someone!

Happy coding! :)




"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
Normally if you install WordPress on a shared host, it is very straightforward. You don't even need to think about the FTP user in order to upload plugins or update the base code.

If you, instead, have it set up in a VPS, like digital ocean or Vultr, like me, that might not be as simple as that and will depend on how your server is configured.

My Setup

  • webserver: caddy + php-fpm
  • caddy owned by user1
  • fpm owned by www-data

With a setup like this, the important is to know who owns the fpm process.

You can check it with:
ps aux | grep fpm -> mine is www-data, I will assume it.

This will tell you that the user www-data who needs write file access is the user who owns that process.

So, your WordPress folder should be owned by www-data. This is the first point.
The second one is that the caddy user owner must be in the www-data group so that it also has permissions to handle the files if needed.

After you have the users organized, you must include a line of code in wp-config.php file.
define('FS_METHOD', 'direct');

These were the steps I needed to solve my upload problems.
Hope it can help someone!

Happy coding! :)
posts.plaintext:
Normaly if you install wordpress in a shared host, it is very straightforward.
You don't even need to think about the FTP user in order to upload plugins or
update the base code.

If you, instead, have it set up in a VPS, like digital ocean or Vultr, like me,
that might not be as simple as that and you may be doing a lot of stuff trying
to solve it, but I'm here to tell you what normaly is the problem.

posts.title: Blockspot Conference 2017
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"With all my enthusiasm and willingness to pursue a crypto dev career, I asked for a day off and went to the first, that I know of, blockchain/cryptocurrencies conference in Portugal, [Blockspot](https://blockspot.co).

Here I will write a bit of what happened...

It wasn't cheap for someone like me (**20% off if you paid with crypto, thumbs up!**), but it brought a lot of new concepts and cutting-edge companies' names and technologies that I hadn't heard of.

![Twitter by @futurebehind](/content/images/2017/11/DOgK5ROWkAAU9Vu.jpg)*from @futurebehind twitter*

It started with a panel talking about [Blockchain](https://www.blockchain.com/) and the applications of it in the corporate world with [Luís Roque](https://www.linkedin.com/in/luisbrasroque/), [Justin Wu](https://www.linkedin.com/in/justinwuetherify/), [Sebastião Lencastre](https://www.linkedin.com/in/sebastiaolancastre), [Paulo Rodrigues](https://www.linkedin.com/in/paulojacintorodrigues/) and [Yegor Karatov](https://www.linkedin.com/in/yegor-karatov-12588686/).
Their main points about why blockchain is entering the corporative world were around cost reductions and maintaining an order in chaos. This means having a worldwide cross-borders "single source of trust" where all the processes of whichever business can talk to and trust its information. It was also grasped why the big tech players, such as [IBM](https://www.ibm.com/), [Microsoft](https://www.microsoft.com) and [Oracle](https://www.oracle.com/), are into R&D and counseling blockchain business integrations, because they will facilitate any kind of business to integrate a blockchain just as they made it possible to any business have a pay-as-you-go cloud infrastructure.
They are the state-of-the-art guys, and they will make money helping others developing this tech.

![Twitter by @futurebehind](/content/images/2017/11/DOgiqBXXkAIpAxM.jpg)*from @futurebehind twitter*

[Fernando Gutierrez](https://www.linkedin.com/in/fernandogutierrez/) from DASH core team was also there and showed us, or at least me, that Bitcoin is probably the MVP of cryptocurrencies, letting [DASH](https://www.dash.org/) lead for the best crypto in ease of use for programmers and non-tech users and distributing the incentives way better through the network. 
He also mentioned three things I hadn't heard of: 
* [Masternodes](https://www.dash.org/masternodes2/), that need to have 1000DASH as collateral and facilitate features such as InstantSend and PrivateSend, that are what the name says they are;
* [DAPI](https://cointelegraph.com/news/worlds-first-dapi-decentralized-application-programming-interface), which is a decentralized API that facilitates other applications querying the blockchain without having to go directly to it, but talking with a subset, randomly picked, of masternodes in which they know, mathematically, they can trust.
* [DASH DRIVE](https://github.com/dashpay/dash-roadmap), which lets you save and query decentralized user object data, outside the blockchain. It is using the IPFS (InterPlanetary File System Protocol) that gives content addresses to data, instead of location addresses.

> "Don't rely on government to protect you. On Internet and Blockchain, you are alone." - Fernando Gutierrez

Fernando participated in the next forum, regarding the legalization of Blockchain, and what I really enjoyed he said was "Don't rely on government to protect you. In Internet and Blockchain, you are alone.", just like in life, you are born and die alone, just you.
Don't get that normal feeling that government will always (or never) have your back because this is a very difficult to regulate and keep track of technology. Governments are always a step behind the markets, never the other way around.

I think it will be inevitable that governments unleash the markets. Another way, it will always be a cat and dog run. Long live guys like Henry Thoreau that knew this from the beginning.

![Twitter by @futurebehind](/content/images/2017/11/DOn0r-dW4AA6Shc.jpg)*from @futurebehind twitter*

Another interesting topic was ICO's and the speakers, [Denis Suslov](https://www.linkedin.com/in/denissuslov/), [Paulo Rodrigo Trezentos](https://www.linkedin.com/in/paulotrezentos/) and [Nuno Correia](https://www.linkedin.com/in/nuno-correia-659175151/), gave their advice on how to spot a good or bad ICO:
* Do they have a team responsible for legal terms?
* Which role does the token play in the project?
* Read the white paper (protocol) and the crowd sale document (roadmap) carefully!

Choose wisely, as more than 90% of them don't even take off.
Important to mention that despite all the unregulated gray area that lays around ICO's and cryptocurrencies, they advised not to fear it, to follow the existing rules, like hiring through the normal system, and most important, **pay taxes**. That's what governments want - if you do it, most of the times you'll be fine.

> "Keep complexity off-chain. Only validate it in-chain" - Gonçalo Sá

[Gonçalo Sá](https://www.linkedin.com/in/gnsps/) gave a talk about the power of smart contracts. 
While talking about [DAO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_DAO_(organization)), he mentioned that it was an ultra-complex pile of code all bundled together, comparing it with the **ethereum mindset of smart contracts, making them the smallest unit in a Decentralized Autonomous Organization**. That's evolution, breaking down a pile of code into its atomic units.
Another important remark was the fact that smart contracts should not be complex, but rather simple pieces of code that validate the external complex code. 

[Anderson Mccutheon](https://www.linkedin.com/in/ender/) talked about the decentralized web and attention span.
He spoke about the concept of content and attention monetization as all companies are fighting for it as their core income source. More attention equals more user data that can be sold. [Synereo](http://www.synereo.com/) and [WildSpark](https://wildspark.me/) are two of his projects that will attempt to break the status quo.

> "Stop asking for permission!" - Graham de Barra

![http://www.grupoescolar.com](/content/images/2017/11/B5A8E.jpg)*from grupoescolar.com*

There were a few more talks, but this last guy, [Graham de Barra](https://www.linkedin.com/in/graham-de-barra-81613a24/), caught all my attention when he mixed all these tech topics with philosophy and history.
The conference was in the "Câmara de Comércio de Lisboa", a beautiful structure with all these magnificent paintings of old Portuguese kings. 
He made us realize that these guys were the ones that were not giving us freedom of choice, and compared blockchain with the carnations in the 25th of April of 1974 Portuguese revolution, where instead of using bullets to fight the oppressor regime, we put flowers in the tip of the army's guns.
Blockchain will give us freedom of choice, freedom of doing what we want and not having to ask for permission. 
Graham is the CEO of  [Opera Incubator](http://operaincubator.com/), based in Ireland. Mainly addressed [festy](http://festy.ie/), a new way of paying in closed places, such as festivals or events.
This is the beginning of cryptocurrencies payments, and festy will disrupt part of the status quo.

I hope I can work with any of these guy in the future. Until then, I can only assure myself that I will keep working!

Special thanks to Justin Wu and the organization.

For reference, I'll just leave here the most important concepts, companies and techs that all these wonderful speakers mentioned:
* [Etherify](http://etherify.io/)
* [Hyperledger](http://www.hyperledger.org/)
* [Ethereum Enterprise Alliance](https://entethalliance.org/)
* [Fabric Blockchain](https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release/)
* [JP Morgan Quorum](https://www.jpmorgan.com/global/Quorum)
* [Everledger](https://www.everledger.io/)
* [Aadhaar Identity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aadhaar)
* [Mediachain](http://www.mediachain.io/) (Spotify is using it)
* [Switzerland's Zug Crypto valley](https://cryptovalley.swiss/)
* [Abypay](https://www.abypay.com/)
* [Finom](https://finom.io/)
* [Salt Lending](https://www.saltlending.com/) (Shapeshift's collateralized loans)
* [NAU](https://nau.io)
* [Consensys](https://consensys.net/)
* [Uport](https://www.uport.me/)
* [Truebit](https://truebit.io/)
* [Ethereum Casper](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ycF0WFHY5kc)
* [Thin applications, fat protocols](https://medium.com/@deekay/fat-protocols-are-only-half-the-story-6a91f68202a8)
* [Token curated registry](https://medium.com/@ilovebagels/token-curated-registries-1-0-61a232f8dac7)
* [Ethereum Oracles](https://blog.ethereum.org/2014/07/22/ethereum-and-oracles)
* [BitInka](https://www.bitinka.com/)
* [Synereo](http://www.synereo.com/)
* [WildSparks](https://wildspark.me/)
* [Festy](http://festy.me/)
* [Opera Incubator](http://operaincubator.com/)

![IMG_20171113_183200](/content/images/2017/11/IMG_20171113_183200.jpg)*from my own photo album*"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
With all my enthusiasm and willingness to pursue a crypto dev career, I asked for a day off and went to the first, that I know of, blockchain/cryptocurrencies conference in Portugal, Blockspot.

Here I will write a bit of what happened...

It wasn't cheap for someone like me (20% off if you paid with crypto, thumbs up!), but it brought a lot of new concepts and cutting-edge companies' names and technologies that I hadn't heard of.

from @futurebehind twitter

It started with a panel talking about Blockchain and the applications of it in the corporate world with Luís Roque, Justin Wu, Sebastião Lencastre, Paulo Rodrigues and Yegor Karatov.
Their main points about why blockchain is entering the corporative world were around cost reductions and maintaining an order in chaos. It was also grasped why the big tech players, such as IBM, Microsoft and Oracle, are into R&D and counseling blockchain business integrations, because they will facilitate any kind of business to integrate a blockchain just as they made it possible to any business have a pay-as-you-go cloud infrastructure.
They are the state-of-the-art guys, and they will make money helping others developing this tech.

from @futurebehind twitter

Fernando Gutierrez from DASH core team was also there and showed us, or at least me, that Bitcoin is probably the MVP of cryptocurrencies, letting DASH lead for the best crypto in ease of use for programmers and non-tech users and distributing the incentives way better through the network.
He also mentioned three things I hadn't heard of:

  • Masternodes, that need to have 1000DASH as collateral and facilitate features such as InstantSend and PrivateSend, that are what the name says they are;
  • DAPI, which is a decentralized API that facilitates other applications querying the blockchain without having to go directly to it, but talking with a subset, randomly picked, of masternodes in which they know, mathematically, they can trust.
  • DASH DRIVE, which lets you save and query decentralized user object data, outside the blockchain. It is using the IPFS (InterPlanetary File System Protocol) that gives content addresses to data, instead of location addresses.

"Don't rely on government to protect you. On Internet and Blockchain, you are alone." - Fernando Gutierrez

Fernando participated in the next forum, regarding the legalization of Blockchain, and what I really enjoyed he said was "Don't rely on government to protect you. In Internet and Blockchain, you are alone.", just like in life, you are born and die alone, just you.

I think it will be inevitable that governments unleash the markets. Another way, it will always be a cat and dog run. Long live guys like Henry Thoreau that knew this from the beginning.

from @futurebehind twitter

Another interesting topic was ICO's and the speakers, Denis Suslov, Paulo Rodrigo Trezentos and Nuno Correia, gave their advice on how to spot a good or bad ICO:

  • Which role does the token play in the project?

Important to mention that despite all the unregulated gray area that lays around ICO's and cryptocurrencies, they advised not to fear it, to follow the existing rules, like hiring through the normal system, and most important, pay taxes. That's what governments want - if you do it, most of the times you'll be fine.

Gonçalo Sá gave a talk about the power of smart contracts.
While talking about DAO, he mentioned that it was an ultra-complex pile of code all bundled together, comparing it with the ethereum mindset of smart contracts, making them the smallest unit in a Decentralized Autonomous Organization. "Stop asking for permission!" - Graham de Barra

from grupoescolar.com

There were a few more talks, but this last guy, Graham de Barra, caught all my attention when he mixed all these tech topics with philosophy and history.

This is the beginning of cryptocurrencies payments, and festy will disrupt part of the status quo.

I hope I can work with any of these guy in the future. Until then, I can only assure myself that I will keep working!

Special thanks to Justin Wu and the organization.

For reference, I'll just leave here the most important concepts, companies and techs that all these wonderful speakers mentioned:

  • Etherify
  • Hyperledger
  • Ethereum Enterprise Alliance
  • Fabric Blockchain
  • JP Morgan Quorum
  • Everledger
  • Aadhaar Identity
  • Mediachain (Spotify is using it)
  • Switzerland's Zug Crypto valley

  • Salt Lending (Shapeshift's collateralized loans)

posts.plaintext:
With all my enthusiasm and willingness to pursue a crypto dev career, I asked
for a day off and went to the first, that I know of, blockchain/cryptocurrencies
conference in Portugal.

Here I will write a bit of what happened...

It wasn't cheap (20% off if you paid with crypto), but it brought a lot of new
concepts and cutting-edge companies' names and technologies that I hadn't heard
of.

It started with a panel talking about Blockchain [https://www.blockchain.com/] 
and the applications of it in the corporate world with Luís Roque
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/luisbrasroque/], Justin Wu
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/justinwuetherify/], Sebastião Lencastre
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/sebastiaolancastre], Paulo Rodrigues
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/paulojacintorodrigues/]  and Yegor Karatov
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/yegor-karatov-12588686/].
Their main points about why blockchain is entering the corporative world were
around cost reductions and maintaining an order in chaos. This means having a
worldwide cross-borders "single source of trust" where all the processes of
whichever business can talk to and trust its information. It was also grasped
why the big tech players, such as IBM [https://www.ibm.com/], Microsoft
[https://www.microsoft.com]  and Oracle [https://www.oracle.com/], are into R&D
and counseling blockchain business integrations, because they will facilitate
any kind of business to integrate a blockchain just as they made it possible to
any business have a pay-as-you-go cloud infrastructure.
They are the state-of-the-art guys, and they will make money helping others
developing this tech.

Fernando Gutierrez [https://www.linkedin.com/in/fernandogutierrez/]  from DASH
core team was also there and showed us, or at least me, that Bitcoin is probably
the MVP of cryptocurrencies, letting DASH [https://www.dash.org/]  lead for the
best crypto in ease of use for programmers and non-tech users and distributing
the incentives way better through the network.
He also mentioned three things I hadn't heard of:

 * Masternodes [https://www.dash.org/masternodes2/], that need to have 1000DASH
   as collateral and facilitate features such as InstantSend and PrivateSend,
   that are what the name says they are;
 * DAPI
   [https://cointelegraph.com/news/worlds-first-dapi-decentralized-application-programming-interface]
   , which is a decentralized API that facilitates other applications querying
   the blockchain without having to go directly to it, but talking with a
   subset, randomly picked, of masternodes in which they know, mathematically,
   they can trust.
 * DASH DRIVE [https://github.com/dashpay/dash-roadmap], which lets you save and
   query decentralized user object data, outside the blockchain. It is using the
   IPFS (InterPlanetary File System Protocol) that gives content addresses to
   data, instead of location addresses.

"Don't rely on government to protect you. On Internet and Blockchain, you are
alone." - Fernando Gutierrez

Fernando participated in the next forum, regarding the legalization of
Blockchain, and what I really enjoyed he said was "Don't rely on government to
protect you. In Internet and Blockchain, you are alone.", just like in life, you
are born and die alone, just you.
Don't get that normal feeling that government will always (or never) have your
back because this is a very difficult to regulate and keep track of technology.
Governments are always a step behind the markets, never the other way around.

I think it will be inevitable that governments unleash the markets. Another way,
it will always be a cat and dog run. Long live guys like Henry Thoreau that knew
this from the beginning.

Another interesting topic was ICO's and the speakers, Denis Suslov
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/denissuslov/], Paulo Rodrigo Trezentos
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/paulotrezentos/]  and Nuno Correia
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/nuno-correia-659175151/], gave their advice on how
to spot a good or bad ICO:

 * Do they have a team responsible for legal terms?
 * Which role does the token play in the project?
 * Read carefully the white paper (protocol) and the crowd sale document
   (roadmap)
   Choose carefully as more than 90% of them don't even take off.
   Important to mention that despite all the unregulated gray area that lays
   around ICO's and cryptocurrencies, they advised not to fear it, to follow the
   existing rules, as hiring through the normal system, and most important, pay
   taxes. That's what governments want - if you do it, most of the times you'll
   be fine.

"Keep complexity off-chain. Only validate it in-chain" - Gonçalo Sá

Gonçalo Sá [https://www.linkedin.com/in/gnsps/]  gave a talk about the power of
smart contracts. While talking about DAO
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_DAO_(organization)], he mentioned that it was
an ultra-complex pile of code all bundled together, comparing it with the
ethereum mindset of smart contracts, wanting to make them the smallest unit in a
Decentralized Autonomous Organization. That's evolution, breaking down a pile of
code into its atomic units.
Another important remark was the fact that smart contracts should not be
complex, but rather simple pieces of code that validate the external complex
code.

Anderson Mccutheon [https://www.linkedin.com/in/ender/]  talked about the
decentralized web and attention span.
He spoke about the concept of content and attention monetization as all
companies are fighting for it as their core income source. More attention equals
more user data that can be sold. Synereo and WildSparks are two of his projects
that will attempt to break the status quo.

"Stop asking for permission!" - Graham de Barra

There were a few more talks, but this last guy, Graham de Barra
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/graham-de-barra-81613a24/], caught all my attention
when he mixed all these tech topics with philosophy and history.
The conference was in the "Câmara de Comércio de Lisboa", a beautiful structure
with all these magnificent paintings of old Portuguese kings. He made us realize
that these guys were the ones that were not giving us freedom of choice, and
compared blockchain with the carnations in the 25th of April of 1974 Portuguese
revolution, where instead of using bullets to fight the oppressor regime, we put
flowers in the tip of the army's guns.
Blockchain will give us freedom of choice, freedom of doing what we want and not
having to ask for permission. He is the CEO of Opera Incubator, based in
Ireland. Mainly addressed festy [http://festy.ie/], a new way of paying in
closed places, such as festivals or events.
This is the beginning of cryptocurrencies payments, and festy will disrupt part
of the status quo.

I hope I can work with any of these guy in the future. Until then, I can only
assure myself that I will keep working!

Special thanks to Justin Wu and the organization.

For reference, I'll just leave here the most important concepts, companies and
techs that all this wonderfull speakers mentioned:

 * Hyperledger [http://www.hyperledger.org/]
 * Ethereum Enterprise Alliance [https://entethalliance.org/]
 * Fabric Blockchain [https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release/]
 * JP Morgan Quorum [https://www.jpmorgan.com/global/Quorum]
 * Everledger [https://www.everledger.io/]
 * Aadhaar Identity [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aadhaar]
 * Mediachain [http://www.mediachain.io/]  (Spotify is using it)
 * Switzerland's Zug Crypto valley [https://cryptovalley.swiss/]
 * Abypay [https://www.abypay.com/]
 * Finom [https://finom.io/]
 * Salt Lending [https://www.saltlending.com/]  (Shapeshift's collateralized
   loans)
 * NAU [https://nau.io]
 * Consensys [https://consensys.net/]
 * Uport [https://www.uport.me/]
 * Truebit [https://truebit.io/]
 * Ethereum Casper [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ycF0WFHY5kc]
 * Thin applications, fat protocols
   [https://medium.com/@deekay/fat-protocols-are-only-half-the-story-6a91f68202a8]
 * Token curated registry
   [https://medium.com/@ilovebagels/token-curated-registries-1-0-61a232f8dac7]
 * Ethereum Oracles [https://blog.ethereum.org/2014/07/22/ethereum-and-oracles]
 * BitInka [https://www.bitinka.com/]
 * Synero [http://www.synereo.com/]
 * WildSparks [https://wildspark.me/]
 * Festy [http://festy.me/]

posts.title: How to deploy Angular and nodeJS express app in Heroku
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"![expressplusangular-2](/content/images/2017/11/expressplusangular-2.png)
My main problem was to understand how could I bundle together a client-server app with **[angular](https://angular.io/)** and **[express](https://expressjs.com/)** frameworks.
> I started by deploying two different apps, but after all, understood how all of this could be done in one app only.
## Requirements
* [nodejs](https://nodejs.org/en/)
* [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/)
* [git](https://git-scm.com/)
* [heroku-cli](https://heroku.com)
## Create app
Just start an express app as you usually do it, i user [express-generator](https://www.npmjs.com/package/express-generator) installed globally:

`$ express example-app`
`$ cd example-app`
`$ npm install`
`$ git init`
# Heroku create app
[Heroku getting-started docs](https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/getting-started-with-nodejs#introduction) are a very good resource, feel free to follow it as I will go very fast on it. 

First of all, you should log in with the heroku-cli, so that heroku know who you are: `$ heroku login`
After, you should create an heroku app in their servers and associated with your account: `$ heroku crate example-app`

Heroku will give you two links:
Web URL: `https://example-app.herokuapp.com/`
and a GIT repository: `https://git.heroku.com/example-app.git`

Now you need to set the remote repository like that **git url** you got:
`$ git remote add heroku https://git.heroku.com/example-app.git`

You are ready to go!
## Angular inside express
Having an express app, you can generate an angular app, separated or already inside of it.

I did it separately, and that's how I'm going to explain it.

My project structure was like this:
```
app\
    client\ (angular)
    server\ (express)
```
    
And in the end it looked like this:
```
app\ (express)
    package.json
    bin\
    node_modules\
    views\
    ...
    public\ (angular inside)
```
        
**In essence, angular is the static files served by the express app.**

# Tweaks needed
I will be assuming your angular app is building to a dist folder, with it's path as `app/public/dist`.
* Add all angular package.json dependencies to **express** package.json
* Change, in `app.js` the path to the static folder:
`app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public/dist')));`
* angular-cli.json:
    * Tell where anfular app is:
        ```
        "root": "public/src",
        "outDir": "public/dist",
        ```
    * Tell it, relatively, also, where **schema, scripts and styles** are (I just added "../" before "node_modules" as angular needs to get them from the express' node_modules folder):
        ```
        "$schema": "../../node_modules/@angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json"
        ...
        "styles": [
            "../../node_modules/bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css",
            "styles.css"
          ],
          "scripts": [
            "../../node_modules/jquery/dist/jquery.min.js",
            "../../node_modules/tether/dist/js/tether.min.js",  
            "../../node_modules/bootstrap/dist/js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js"
          ]
          ```

# Conclusion
After all, it seems pretty simple, but I didn't find any resource that explained it as simple as I needed, so I decided to post this.

### Quick Recap: 
* Add angular to the static express folder.
* Add all dependencies to express' package.json in the app folder.
* Change static folder in `app.js`
* Tweak the `angular-cli.json` for it to know where your angular app is and how to get to the node_modules folder.

This was my approach to it, if you have a better way, please leave a comment! :)
    
"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
My main problem was to understand how could I bundle together a client-server app with angular and express frameworks.

I started by deploying two different apps, but after all, understood how all of this could be done in one app only.

Requirements

  • nodejs
  • npm
  • git
  • heroku-cli

Create app

Just start an express app as you usually do it, i user express-generator installed globally:

$ express example-app
$ cd example-app
$ npm install
$ git init

Heroku create app

Heroku getting-started docs are a very good resource, feel free to follow it as I will go very fast on it.

First of all, you should log in with the heroku-cli, so that heroku know who you are: $ heroku login
After, you should create an heroku app in their servers and associated with your account: $ heroku crate example-app

Heroku will give you two links:
Web URL: https://example-app.herokuapp.com/
and a GIT repository: https://git.heroku.com/example-app.git

Now you need to set the remote repository like that git url you got:
$ git remote add heroku https://git.heroku.com/example-app.git

You are ready to go!

Angular inside express

Having an express app, you can generate an angular app, separated or already inside of it.

I did it separately, and that's how I'm going to explain it.

My project structure was like this:

app\
    client\ (angular)
    server\ (express)

And in the end it looked like this:

app\ (express)
    package.json
    bin\
    node_modules\
    views\
    ...
    public\ (angular inside)

In essence, angular is the static files served by the express app.

Tweaks needed

I will be assuming your angular app is building to a dist folder, with it's path as app/public/dist.

  • Add all angular package.json dependencies to express package.json
  • Change, in app.js the path to the static folder:
    app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public/dist')));
  • angular-cli.json:
    • Tell where anfular app is:
      "root": "public/src",
"outDir": "public/dist",
    • Tell it, relatively, also, where schema, scripts and styles are (I just added "../" before "node_modules" as angular needs to get them from the express' node_modules folder):
      "$schema": "../../node_modules/@angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json"
...
"styles": [
    "../../node_modules/bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css",
    "styles.css"
  ],
  "scripts": [
    "../../node_modules/jquery/dist/jquery.min.js",
    "../../node_modules/tether/dist/js/tether.min.js",  
    "../../node_modules/bootstrap/dist/js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js"
  ]
  ```

Conclusion

After all, it seems pretty simple, but I didn't find any resource that explained it as simple as I needed, so I decided to post this.

Quick Recap:

  • Add angular to the static express folder.
  • Add all dependencies to express' package.json in the app folder.
  • Change static folder in app.js
  • Tweak the angular-cli.json for it to know where your angular app is and how to get to the node_modules folder.

This was my approach to it, if you have a better way, please leave a comment! :)
posts.plaintext:
My main problem was to understand how could I bundle together a client-server
app with angular [https://angular.io/]  and express [https://expressjs.com/] 
frameworks.

I started by deploying two different apps, but after all, understood how all of
this could be done in one app only.

Requirements
 * nodejs [https://nodejs.org/en/]
 * npm [https://www.npmjs.com/]
 * git [https://git-scm.com/]
 * heroku-cli [https://heroku.com]

Create app
Just start an express app as you usually do it, i user express-generator
[https://www.npmjs.com/package/express-generator]  installed globally:

$ express example-app
$ cd example-app
$ npm install
$ git init

Heroku create app
Heroku getting-started docs  are a very good resource, feel free to follow it as
I will go very fast on it.

First of all, you should log in with the heroku-cli, so that heroku know who you
are: $ heroku login
After, you should create an heroku app in their servers and associated with your
account: $ heroku crate example-app

Heroku will give you two links:
Web URL: https://example-app.herokuapp.com/
and a GIT repository: https://git.heroku.com/example-app.git

Now you need to set the remote repository like that git url  you got:
$ git remote add heroku https://git.heroku.com/example-app.git

You are ready to go!

Angular inside express
Having an express app, you can generate an angular app, separated or already
inside of it.

I did it separately, and that's how I'm going to explain it.

My project structure was like this:

app\
    client\ (angular)
    server\ (express)


And in the end it looked like this:

app\ (express)
    package.json
    bin\
    node_modules\
    views\
    ...
    public\ (angular inside)


In essence, angular is the static files served by the express app.

Tweaks needed
I will be assuming your angular app is building to a dist folder, with it's path
as app/public/dist.

 * Add all angular package.json dependencies to express  package.json
 * Change, in app.js  the path to the static folder:
   app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public/dist')));
 * angular-cli.json: * Tell where anfular app is:"root": "public/src",
      "outDir": "public/dist",
      
      
      
    * Tell it, relatively, also, where schema, scripts and styles  are (I just
      added "../" before "node_modules" as angular needs to get them from the
      express' node_modules folder):"$schema": "../../node_modules/@angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json"
      ...
      "styles": [
          "../../node_modules/bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css",
          "styles.css"
        ],
        "scripts": [
          "../../node_modules/jquery/dist/jquery.min.js",
          "../../node_modules/tether/dist/js/tether.min.js",  
          "../../node_modules/bootstrap/dist/js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js"
        ]
        ```
      
      
      
      
   
   

Conclusion
After all, it seems pretty simple, but I didn't find any resource that explained
it as simple as I needed, so I decided to post this.

Quick Recap:
 * Add angular to the static express folder.
 * Add all dependencies to express' package.json in the app folder.
 * Change static folder in app.js
 * Tweak the angular-cli.json  for it to know where your angular app is and how
   to get to the node_modules folder.

This was my approach to it, if you have a better way, please leave a comment! :)
posts.custom_excerpt: How to deploy a single nodejs app with express and angular to heroku.

posts.title: Bitcoin's coins are unspent received transactions  (UTXO)
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"In order to understand new things, it's always easier if you can related them by improved in existing ideas. That's why bitcoin is called as it is and not bitUTXO, because what you have in bitcoin as coins are in fact UTXOs.

I'm finishing Andreas A. book, the Internet of Money, and he is so right saying we have a lot of bad methafors for the bitcoin world because we want to make them an improvement of the type of money we already know.

The problem is that if we do it, people will tend to understand it superficially but will struggle to master it. We should probably make some better methapors for more people to understand it proparly. 

Here is my sugestion.

In bitcoin you need an address, that address is a mailbox where you receive your money. Those mailboxes can only be unlocked by their keys and you can't brute force, so anyone who has a key to a mailbox can unlock it.
I think if we understood addresses as physical mailboxs than needed key(s) to be opened and could not be brute forced, it would 



Mailbox keychain"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
In order to understand new things, it's always easier if you can related them by improved in existing ideas. That's why bitcoin is called as it is and not bitUTXO, because what you have in bitcoin as coins are in fact UTXOs.

I'm finishing Andreas A. book, the Internet of Money, and he is so right saying we have a lot of bad methafors for the bitcoin world because we want to make them an improvement of the type of money we already know.

The problem is that if we do it, people will tend to understand it superficially but will struggle to master it. We should probably make some better methapors for more people to understand it proparly.

Here is my sugestion.

In bitcoin you need an address, that address is a mailbox where you receive your money. Those mailboxes can only be unlocked by their keys and you can't brute force, so anyone who has a key to a mailbox can unlock it.
I think if we understood addresses as physical mailboxs than needed key(s) to be opened and could not be brute forced, it would

Mailbox keychain
posts.plaintext:
In order to understand new things, it's always easier if you can related them by
improved in existing ideas. That's why bitcoin is called as it is and not
bitUTXO, because what you have in bitcoin as coins are in fact UTXOs.

I'm finishing Andreas A. book, the Internet of Money, and he is so right saying
we have a lot of bad methafors for the bitcoin world because we want to make
them an improvement of the type of money we already know.

The problem is that if we do it, people will tend to understand it superficially
but will struggle to master it. We should probably make some better methapors
for more people to understand it proparly.

Here is my sugestion.

In bitcoin you need an address, that address is a mailbox where you receive your
money. Those mailboxes can only be unlocked by their keys and you can't brute
force, so anyone who has a key to a mailbox can unlock it.
I think if we understood addresses as physical mailboxs than needed key(s) to be
opened and could not be brute forced, it would

Mailbox keychain
